text:
As has been explained to you, the quantified contribution of water vapor to the GHE is ~50%, not "75-90%" (Schmidt et al. 2010). Water vapor is the least selective of the selectively-absorbing GHGs, but as it is not well-mixed in the atmosphere, with most of its radiative efficacy occurring near the surface. The Earth's energy budget is determined at the TOA, where CO₂ is still very much a player.

Water vapor cannot initiate warming on its own. Because its mixing ratio is determined by temperature, something else (like CO₂) must raise the temperature to enable an increase in water vapor. It is a positive feedback amplifying the initial forcing.

You should likely stop adding assertions. Each one is mistaken.

text:
Doc's idea meshes with Josh Gordon's surtax proposal.  See:  http://torontolife.com/real-estate/qa-joshua-gordon-researcher-blames-buyers-rising-home-prices-toronto/.  Both make sense.

Re KM1's comments, a start would be to set the bar at higher surtaxes/property taxes for purchases made with "non-Canadian-taxed" income.  This is doable if the provinces and feds cooperate to make all RE transactions contingent on a thorough review of income tax filings of the purchaser. That's the only way to know if Canadian income tax has been fully paid on all the money being used for the purchase. Money from outside Canada would only be suitable if it was duly taxed in a country that has a fair tax agreement with Canada. "Gift" money would only be suitable if one could show the source, and that source's income tax filings revealed tax duly paid in Canada or in a country with a fair tax agreement with Canada.  No sale if taxes paid aren't commensurate with the RE purchase price.

text:
Firstly, I am just confused (though not surprised) that a tiny and tentative rise in the overnight rate can trigger wailing about the fiscal policies of a government that left office in 1984.

As far as your questions go, I am sure that the booms and bust of latin america are a fascinating area of study but they don't bear much relevance to anything going on in this country. Over time government books should roughly balance, and will (one way or the other) but surely the salient question is: why have rates been so low for so long? One answer is probably the mental hangover of the 70s and 80s left politicians incapable of seeing that deflation was the real enemy, not inflation, leaving them incapable of engaging in robust deficit spending when it would have done some good. Cental banks were left to pick up the slack with pretty poor results. As far as what would happen in another finacial crisis goes, if it was as bad as the last I would hope deficits would skyrocket, as they should...

text:
Like I pointed out, my first house was a starter house, and based on the pictures on zillow, still is.  Small, crappy, not great neighborhood, but the estimate is almost 400k for it.  As someone who was working a crappy paying blue collar job at the time, I can attest to how hard it was to save the 26k we needed for a downpayment.  I'm not sure that were I in that job today, even making more, based on going pay rates, that I would have been able to buy anything that didn't involve a monster of a commute.  That commute also has associated costs, especially since our transit system here, kinda sucks.

As I said, I think that people do need to take a hard look at the fact that housing has gone up at 3 or 4x the rate of wage growth, before just writing off millennials as whiners.  I find that they whine about many things that are just how things have always been, but in this case, I'm not sure their whining isn't entirely accurate.

text:
lol! Yeah, there are some truly ridiculous degrees out there. My parents didn't help me whatsoever, but I knew I had to get a college education because I wanted to do better than my lower-middle class parents. I took a year of community college (free w/Pell Grants because we were po'), then joined the military for 4 years to get the GI Bill and took classes here and there while still in the military, then got out and finished my degree at a public university full time for about 2.5 years. But that was the '90s and college was cheaper. 

I struggled in my 20s and early 30s to figure things out and work my way up, but I know I wouldn't be bringing home 6 figures today without my college degree. We're saving for our kids' college and have them in tutoring to keep them ahead of their peers. But I still don't know if we'll have enough to cover 100% of their tuition. By then (in 9 years), we may still need to pitch in to help them. But my opinion is that a degree is a necessity these days.

text:
The short version is that if it were considered an act of war, then there would be no liability. 

The civil case from the US was won based on Khadr's presence (not necessarily actions) being an 'act of terrorism' under the US Anti-Terrorism Act (ATA), which is similar to the Canadian Justice for Victims of Terrorism act (JVT)

So even if the GITMO murder conviction is eventually expunged, and that would seem likely, and perhaps even justified; there is ample evidence to uphold the civil judgment.  

The Ontario court's job at the moment is to evaluate whether Khadr's settlement funds and/or other assets should be frozen until the Ontario court can judge whether the civil case can be enforced in Ontario. 

Contrary to popular belief, the Ontario court's job is not to relitigate the civil suit.

text:
It's a lot more than the rare exception. Count up all the lightbulbs in your house, and probably half of them get used infrequently or for just a few minutes at a time (hallways, closets, the garage, the crawl space/storage room, pantry, guest bedroom, etc).  Many people never even have to replace those bulbs at all because they last for the entire time they live in that house.  

What you're advocating is throwing out working bulbs prematurely. No, most people aren't going to do that. Ironically because (in part) that enviros and others scream at people for throwing perfectly functional products in the landfill.  I've done just that in my highest usage rooms (replaced the existing BR30 ceiling floods with LEDs), but it is a waste to discard working bulbs. That's not a "market forces" thing, that's a "don't waste" thing.

On flashlights, I've had the AA cells corrode on a few of my small LED flashlights too. That's not a result of the bulb, it's a result of the batteries.

text:
I don't know that anyone should be holding their breath on interest rates going up much further.  Chances are interest rates hovering around 1% are "the new normal", just as they have been in Japan for about 25 years now.

Economic cycles are, well, cyclical.  We are probably pretty close to the peak of the current cycle and central banks are only just barely starting to remove the "emergency stimulus".  What that suggests to me is that we will go beyond the 'peak' and into the next global slowdown WELL before we finish the job of removing the "stimulus" put in place during the last slowdown.

The real problem here is that, when the next recession hits, we won't have much room available for traditional monetary stimulus.

text:
First, although it is the far-right, holding a memorial service for somebody who holds hateful views is quite different from hate speech, so there shouldn't be any question of this being illegal.

Second, "would you be ok with X?" is a very different from asking "should X be prohibited?" Just because something is bad, or even despicable, doesn't necessarily mean the government should make any effort to prevent it. The very definition of free society is that we have broad leeway, without the government trying to sort out 'good' from 'bad' speech. This doesn't mean we as a society have to tolerate it, but the principle of government non-interference is important. Even current hate speech laws over-reach, in the view of many free speech advocates.

With Ottawa now moving to remove blasphemy from the criminal code, we are going in the right direction on protected speech. Let's not reverse tack on issues like this.

Text: First, although it is the far-right, holding a memorial service for somebody who holds hateful views is quite different from hate speech, so there shouldn't be any question of this being illegal.

Second, "would you be ok with X?" is a very different from asking "should X be prohibited?" Just because something is bad, or even despicable, doesn't necessarily mean the government should make any effort to prevent it. The very definition of free society is that we have broad leeway, without the government trying to sort out 'good' from 'bad' speech. This doesn't mean we as a society have to tolerate it, but the principle of government non-interference is important. Even current hate speech laws over-reach, in the view of many free speech advocates.

Deserts are spreading and we are losing farmland to it in earth's midband.  Sudan, Somalia, Syria, Iraq etc.   Plants may respond to increases in CO2 but their grain yield does not improve.  Crops need 20" of rainfall/irrigation and without that the CO2 discussion is moot.  Sparse wild plants may well benefit in this regime but they aren't much in the way of food potential.

Global warming is broadening the arid/desert belts further north as the Hadley cells dump their moisture further north.  Hadley cells (rain patterns) will be the next hot topic in the public domain probably.

Cheers,
John Meyer

text:
The Scientific Method:
Purpose- What do you want to learn?
Research- Find out as much as you can.
Hypothesis- Try to predict the answer to the problem. Another term for hypothesis is ‘educated guess’. This is usually stated like ” If I…(do something) then…(this will occur)
Experiment- The fun part! Design a test or procedure to confirm or disprove your hypothesis.
Analysis- Record what happened during the experiment. Also known as ‘data’.
Conclusion- Review the data and check to see if your hypothesis was correct.

The AGW Method:
Purpose: What do you want to convince people of?
Research:  Only pursue research that supports your objective by providing correlation, even if it doesn't prove causation.
Hypothesis:  Try to predict the answer to the problem.  (Models)
Experiment:  If the results don't confirm your predictions, change the data history and current sources to make the results fit the predictions.

You can't do an experiment because there are far too many variables.

Purpose- What do you want to learn?

Hypothesis- Try to predict the answer to the problem. Another term for hypothesis is ‘educated guess’. This is usually stated like ” If I…(do something) then…(this will occur)
Experiment- The fun part! Design a test or procedure to confirm or disprove your hypothesis.
Analysis- Record what happened during the experiment. Also known as ‘data’.
Conclusion- Review the data and check to see if your hypothesis was correct.

The AGW Method:
Purpose: What do you want to convince people of?
Research:  Only pursue research that supports your objective by providing correlation, even if it doesn't prove causation.
Hypothesis:  Try to predict the answer to the problem.  (Models)
Experiment:  If the results don't confirm your predictions, change the data history and current sources to make the results fit the predictions.

You can't do an experiment because there are far too many variables.

text:
John, I agree with your post about the population crisis but our deserts are in fact getting greener due to CO2 fertilization.

CSIRO research shows the CO2 fertilization effect occurs where elevated CO2 enables a leaf during photosynthesis to extract more carbon from the air or lose less water to the air, or both. 

Essentially, plants in the desert are using far less of the limited water the area receives and are slowly encroaching in deserts like the Sahara and in Australia where the research was conducted.

We're only getting increased desertification in areas affected by dramatic human deforestation which has little if anything to do with climate but caused by the forestry industry or locals depleting limited trees for fuel or shelter.

Money from outside Canada would only be suitable if it was duly taxed in a country that has a fair tax agreement with Canada. "Gift" money would only be suitable if one could show the source, and that source's income tax filings revealed tax duly paid in Canada or in a country with a fair tax agreement with Canada. No sale if taxes paid aren't commensurate with the RE purchase price.

Would the provinces and feds ever agree to do such a proposal?  That's up to us.

The problem for him is that the Prime Minister is supposed to be representative of ALL Canadians. Most Canadians will see him FIRST as a Sikh because that is how he is dressing. If he takes the Turban and the blade off he would have a much much greater chance of being elected.  Just my honest personal opinion. I don't see a Sikh in full religious dress getting elected Prime Minster just as we won't have a woman in a hijab or a Catholic priest in full cassock winning the job of PM. I should point out though that Sikhs are truly a model of integration in recent years in every other way, teaching their children about our gov't and culture.

text:
Gary,
While I agree with most of what you've written here, I strongly disagree with your comment about riding side by side being OK.  To me such behavior on narrow curvy roads is arrogant, thoughtless and dangerous, even if legal.
However, in this case there is no evidence they were riding side by side, hence MC's charges are baseless us usual.
To me, all of us, bikers, drivers and pedestrians need to be careful on these country roads (or anyplace else for that matter) watching out for others as well as oneself.
Your advice " I walk along our country road...always facing traffic. As cars approach I and my dog always go to the shoulder and wait for traffic to pass " is excellent, and as you note, most drivers are careful of pedestrians.
My view is that pedestrians, drivers and bikers are similar-- most are good but maybe 10% in each group are thoughtless jerks.  The major difference is that usually  only cars (and other vehicles) kill.

text:
I understand your reaction and I feel your pain.  I was you in 1987 - no chance we could really afford what was on offer.   30 years later I have to respectfully inform you that this is just the way it is.  I've lived through multiple cycles:  1987, the 1989 crash, NDP recession of the 90's and recovery, and 2007/2008 great recession spillover. 

Bottom line is that Toronto is NOT just any other city.  It's unique in Canada.  The prices here are what they are due to a unique mix of factors and pressures based on a real economy and desire for people to live here.  Similar types of factors that drive similar types of prices in New York, London, San Francisco, high-end Chicago and LA.   Like those places, prices will certainly ebb and flow with government regulation changes, the overall economy, inflation, employment, interest rates and great recessions.  However, over time, the desire to live in a place (that is, actual supply and demand) is the only factor driving the housing market.

text:
Again - morally, I am totally in agreement with you. It's preposterous that residents cannot afford to live in the city in which they work. The 15% foreign-buyer tax in Toronto, as well as the vacant residence penalty in Vancouver, seem to be cooling the market somewhat. However, your argument about loopholes kind of proves my point - people will concoct ridiculous scenarios to avoid paying what's owed, and creating a "local wage" tax will only create more opportunity for outrageous claims and expensive lawyers. A non-resident tax helps, certainly, but it is not a magic bullet solution, and it won't stop determined foreign interests from overpaying to park their money here. I'd be open to tying, though! 

Really, my only major disagreement with you, as I've said, is the notion that the government is 100% to blame for this. Some of the blame HAS to reside with homeowners wishing to cash in on a runaway market - the majority of which are Canadian citizens.

text:
The state of civics education in Canada is appalling. Many fail to understand the role of  the judiciary. - although I am sure a good deal of this misunderstanding is rhetoric.

When governments make bad laws, and citizens challenge these laws, and these challenges make their way all the way up to the Supreme Court, *then* the Judges make a ruling. If governments didn't make laws of political convenience then judges wouldn't strike them down. When governments fail to act at all - because the decision would alienate too many voters and citizens make a legal challenge, the courts have no choice but to rule on existing legislation.  

If you don't want or like "activist judges" insist your elected representatives do their jobs and do their jobs well. When they don't, toss them from office.  We don't need hastily created frivolous laws, and we don't need laws of political expediency. The Harper government created a lot to show they were "tough on crime", this is the result we get.

text: While reading this article I felt the writer was spending a lot of time trying to convince readers that opposition to religious symbolism in politics amounts to xenophobia. And then, near the end of the piece, he hints at the actual crux of the matter, which is that Singh is a devout Sikh whose religiously-grounded social values infuse his policy choices, such as his opposition to Ontario's new sex-ed curriculum. This, I believe, is the problem with displaying religiosity in politics as it implies that church and state can't and won't be separated by fundamentalist politicians. Canada is mainly a socially progressive country, where religious fundamentalism is distrusted. Even Harper had to keep his party's Christian social conservatives out of the spotlight to gain and hold power. So maybe Quebec's leftists aren't particularly different from most voters in the rest of Canada in their perspective on religion in politics. To label them as xenophobes seems to me to miss the point.
